text:
*Additionally, I did a lot of research on this issue with Logout:* 

If you do not care about the why, here is a short summary and my plan. I will follow up with the longer explanation for those who want to read it.

*My finding:*
• The reason it is still showing in the application tab in developer tools is because we have to pass the Cookie as Secure, but browsers will not remove the Secure cookie entirely when you are running on HTTP and not HTTPS 
*My Plan to Validate and Fix:* 
• Go through the process of getting a HTTPS cert
• Adding it and verifying I can run both local hosts at HTTPS
• Verify that this truly fixes the problem above
• Assuming it does, document the process of how to do this via a video
• Send to the 3 of you so you can follow the instructions to also add the cert so we are all running on HTTPS

If you do not care about the why, here is a short summary and my plan. I will follow up with the longer explanation for those who want to read it.
My finding:

text:
Here is the longer explanation for the above:

*Recap of issue:*
• sessionId is being changed to null and the cookie is being set to inactive on logout in the HTTP response (as seen in Network Dev Tools)
• But the sessionId is still showing in Application Dev Tools 

*Here is an overview of how it works with notes baked in about relevant findings (bold):*
• When a user clicks the logout button on the front end, the Cookie with the sessionId is sent to the backend
• Backend checks that the sessionId is valid and then changes it to null in the database
• The backend then Sets the Cookie to not have a value, it sets the Max-Age to 0, which immediately sets the cookie to expire
    ◦ _And Merve added the missing piece to the front end code to complete this process with the addition of SessionStorage.removeItem("user"); - great catch <@U0578M93BPE>_ 
    ◦ *However, our cookies are "Secure" and this is why it's still showing in the Application tab, even though we see this in the Header response. I learned that a lot of browsers won't explicitly overwrite this when you are on http and it is a secure cookie* 
        ▪︎ Note, we have to have Secure to pass cookies via cross-site requests (our two diff local hosts), I already tried just removing it.

elements.text: Here is the longer explanation for the above:
Recap of issue:
